```{r setup}
library(k3k2)
```

### Introduction 

The k3k2 package provides tools for computing and visualising second and third order log-cumulants of distributions. 

In this vignette:

* Creating and Printing k3k2 objects 

* Building and Summarising k3k2Diagram objects 

* Visualising k3k2Diagram objects

### Creating and Printing k3k2 Objects

Supply one or more numeric vectors:

```{r}
x1 <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)           # Sample 1
x2 <- c(5, 10, 1000, 60000)      # Sample 2

samples <- k3k2(list(x1, x2))
print.k3k2(samples)
```
Data: User-inputted samples.\
kappa2: Calculated second order log-cumulant value.\
kappa3: Calculated third order log-cumulant value.\

### Building and Summarising a k3k2Diagram

```{r}
diagram <- k3k2Diagram(samples)
summary.k3k2Diagram(diagram)
```
References: Which reference curves are included in visualisation (Gamma, Gamma Inverse as default).\
k3k2 object: Same as output from <print.k3k2(samples)>.

### Visualising k3k2Diagram 

```{r}
plot_k3k2(diagram)
```

This shows $\tilde{\kappa}_3$ on the x-axis and $\tilde{\kappa}_2$ on the y-axis, with reference curves for Gamma and Inverse Gamma distributions.

### Expected Errors

Negative input:

```{r, error=TRUE}
bad <- c(-1, 2, 3)
k3k2(bad)
```

NA values:

```{r, error=TRUE}
bad <- c(NA, 4, 5)
k3k2(bad)
```

Non-k3k2 object in k3k2Diagram:

```{r, error=TRUE}
k3k2Diagram(c(1,2,3))
```
